0-65.scene_title: Introduction to Netherfield Park's New Tenant
0-65.description: Mrs. Bennet informs Mr. Bennet about Netherfield Park being let to Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man from the north of England. The conversation revolves around Mr. Bingley's marital status and the potential for him to marry one of the Bennet daughters.
0-65.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet excitedly shares the news of Netherfield being let to Mr. Bingley and discusses his potential as a suitor for their daughters. Mr. Bennet responds with indifference and sarcasm.
text_phrases: Netherfield Park is let at last
Mrs. Long has just been here
young man of large fortune from the north of England
came down on Monday in a chaise and four
some of his servants are to be in the house by the end of next week

0-65.scene_title: Mr. Bennet's Visit to Mr. Bingley
0-65.description: Mr. Bennet visits Mr. Bingley without informing his wife, surprising her and their daughters with the news later. The scene captures the family dynamics and Mrs. Bennet's obsession with marrying off her daughters.
0-65.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet reveals he has visited Mr. Bingley, much to Mrs. Bennet's astonishment and delight. The daughters and Mrs. Bennet discuss the potential for meeting Mr. Bingley at upcoming social events.
text_phrases: Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley
Mr. Bingley will like it Lizzy
we shall meet him at the assemblies
Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him
wore a blue coat and rode a black horse

66-94.scene_title: Mr. Darcy's Arrival at the Ball
66-94.description: Mr. Darcy draws attention upon entering the ball with his handsome features and noble demeanor, but his pride turns the crowd against him.
66-94.dialog_summary: Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy discuss dancing and partners. Mr. Darcy refuses to dance, expressing disdain for the available partners, which offends Elizabeth Bennet when she overhears.
text_phrases: Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention of the room by his fine, tall person
Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit down for two dances
Mr. Darcy had been standing near enough for her to overhear a conversation

66-94.description: Mrs. Bennet shares her excitement about the ball with Mr. Bennet, praising Mr. Bingley's attention to Jane and expressing disdain for Mr. Darcy's behavior.
66-94.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet excitedly recounts the events of the ball, focusing on Jane's success and Mr. Darcy's rudeness. Mr. Bennet humorously wishes Mr. Bingley had sprained his ankle to avoid dancing so much.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield party
Mr. Bennet still up. With a book he was regardless of time
Mrs. Bennet...we have had a most delightful evening, a most excellent ball

95-130.description: The morning after the Meryton assembly, the Miss Lucases visit the Bennets at Longbourn to discuss the events of the previous evening, particularly focusing on Mr. Bingley's and Mr. Darcy's behavior.
95-130.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet and Miss Lucas discuss Mr. Bingley's preference for Jane Bennet and his interactions at the ball. They also touch upon Mr. Darcy's perceived pride and his lack of sociability, comparing his behavior unfavorably to Mr. Bingley's.
text_phrases: the Miss Lucases visit the Bennets
discuss the events of the previous evening
Mr. Bingley's preference for Jane Bennet

95-130.description: Elizabeth and Charlotte Lucas discuss Jane's prospects with Mr. Bingley, the nature of pride and vanity, and the general unpredictability of happiness in marriage.
95-130.dialog_summary: Charlotte advises Elizabeth on how Jane should behave around Mr. Bingley to secure his affection. They debate the role of pride in personal interactions and the impact of knowing one's partner well before marriage on marital happiness.

131-185.description: Elizabeth observes Mr. Bingley's attentions to her sister while unaware of Mr. Darcy's growing interest in her. Mr. Darcy initially criticizes Elizabeth's appearance but soon acknowledges her pleasing figure and playful manners.
131-185.location: Ballroom at Sir William Lucas's house
text_phrases: figure to be light and pleasing

131-185.scene_title: Conversation and Challenge at the Party
131-185.description: At a large party, Elizabeth and Charlotte discuss Mr. Darcy's peculiar behavior of listening to Elizabeth's conversation. Elizabeth challenges Mr. Darcy about his intentions humorously.
131-185.location: Party at Sir William Lucas's house
131-185.dialog_summary: Elizabeth questions Mr. Darcy's interest in her conversation, and Charlotte remarks on the need for Mr. Darcy to explain his actions.

131-185.description: Elizabeth reluctantly performs a song at the insistence of Miss Lucas. Following her performance, Mary takes over, eager to display her own musical skills, while some guests dance.
131-185.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is persuaded to perform musically despite her reluctance, followed by Mary who is eager to display her skills.
text_phrases: dancing at one end of the room

131-185.description: Sir William Lucas attempts to persuade Elizabeth to dance with Mr. Darcy, but she firmly refuses, despite the polite insistence from both gentlemen.
131-185.dialog_summary: Sir William tries to get Elizabeth to dance with Mr. Darcy, who is polite but Elizabeth declines firmly.
text_phrases: not the least intention of dancing

186-237.description: Mrs. Bennet discusses her daughters and potential suitors, specifically mentioning Colonel Forster in regimentals. Lydia updates about Colonel Forster's and Captain Carter's visits to Miss Watson. A note arrives for Miss Bennet from Miss Bingley, inviting her to dine due to the risk of quarreling from a day-long tête-à-tête.
186-237.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet talks about her daughters and suitors; Lydia mentions the officers' visits; a note arrives from Miss Bingley inviting Jane to dine.
text_phrases: Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William's in his regimentals
the entrance of the footman with a note for Miss Bennet

186-237.scene_title: Jane's Rainy Ride and Subsequent Illness
186-237.description: Jane rides to Netherfield on horseback despite the likelihood of rain, as suggested by Mrs. Bennet. It rains heavily, and Jane becomes ill, leading to her staying at Netherfield longer than planned.
186-237.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet suggests Jane ride on horseback; it rains heavily, and Jane falls ill, leading to an extended stay at Netherfield.
text_phrases: Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback

186-237.description: Elizabeth decides to visit Jane at Netherfield by walking, despite the bad weather and her mother's objections. She arrives muddy and is met with mixed reactions from the Bingley party.
186-237.dialog_summary: Elizabeth walks to Netherfield to visit sick Jane, arriving muddy and is judged by the Bingleys but appreciated by Mr. Bingley.
text_phrases: Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing field after field

238-301.description: Characters discuss Jane Bennet's prospects of marriage given her family's low connections, and express varying opinions on the importance of such connections.
238-301.dialog_summary: Characters discuss Jane Bennet's marriage prospects, her uncles' professions, and the impact of her family's social standing on her chances of marrying well.

238-301.description: Elizabeth declines to play cards and chooses to read a book instead, while the others play loo. Discussion on accomplishments and the ideal of an accomplished woman ensues.
238-301.dialog_summary: Elizabeth opts to read over playing cards, sparking a conversation on women's accomplishments and the qualities of an 'accomplished woman'.

238-301.description: Elizabeth spends the night caring for her sister Jane. In the morning, family discussions and plans are made concerning Jane's health, leading to Mrs. Bennet and her daughters visiting Netherfield.
238-301.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and the Bingleys discuss Jane's health and the need for medical attention. Mrs. Bennet arrives and insists on Jane's severe illness, securing their extended stay at Netherfield.

302-355.description: A lively discussion unfolds among the Bennets and Mr. Bingley about the merits of country life versus town life, with Mrs. Bennet and Mr. Darcy expressing contrasting views.
302-355.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet and Mr. Darcy debate the virtues of the country versus the town, with Mrs. Bennet defending the country and Darcy implying it lacks variety. Bingley tries to diplomatically state the advantages of both. Elizabeth corrects her mother's misunderstanding of Darcy's comments.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner
Darcy, after looking at her for a moment, turned silently away
Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete victory over him, continued her triumph

302-355.description: During a visit, Lydia Bennet boldly reminds Mr. Bingley of his earlier promise to host a ball, much to the delight of Mrs. Bennet.
302-355.dialog_summary: Lydia reminds Mr. Bingley of his promise to give a ball, and he agrees to host it once Jane recovers. Mrs. Bennet and her daughters then leave.
text_phrases: Lydia was a stout, well-grown girl of fifteen
Lydia...abruptly reminded him of his promise

302-355.description: The characters engage in various leisure activities in the drawing room, with Mr. Darcy writing a letter and others playing card games or engaging in conversation.
302-355.dialog_summary: Miss Bingley tries to distract Mr. Darcy as he writes a letter, complimenting him and attempting to engage him in conversation about his sister and his writing. The others are occupied with games and needlework.
object_part_of_object: card games;Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley
text_phrases: Elizabeth joined their party in the drawing-room
Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching the progress of his letter
Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet
Mrs. Hurst was observing their game

356-401.description: A lively discussion unfolds in the drawing room involving Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth, and others, where various opinions and subtle jabs at personal preferences and societal norms are exchanged.
356-401.dialog_summary: The characters engage in a spirited debate about personal intentions, the influence of friendship, and societal expectations. Bingley jests about physical stature affecting deference, while Elizabeth and Darcy discuss the merits of yielding to persuasion without argument.
text_phrases: music books that lay on the instrument
Mr. Darcy's eyes were fixed on her
Miss Bingley moved with alacrity to the piano-forte

356-401.description: After dinner, the ladies and gentlemen separate and then reconvene, engaging in various activities such as reading, discussing, and avoiding card games.
356-401.dialog_summary: Post-dinner, the characters engage in light conversation, with Miss Bingley trying unsuccessfully to capture Darcy's attention while he reads. The idea of a ball is discussed, with differing opinions on its enjoyment.
text_phrases: Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the card-table
Mrs. Hurst playing with her bracelets and rings

402-444.description: Miss Bingley persuades Elizabeth to take a walk around the room to refresh themselves after sitting for a long time. Mr. Darcy observes them and declines to join, explaining his reasons with a touch of criticism.
402-444.dialog_summary: Miss Bingley invites Elizabeth to walk around the room. Mr. Darcy observes and comments on their motives, suggesting they either have secrets or are showing off their figures. Miss Bingley and Elizabeth discuss how to respond to Darcy's remarks.
text_phrases: take a turn about the room
sitting so long in one attitude

402-444.description: Elizabeth and Jane plan their departure from Netherfield back to their home, despite Mrs. Bennet's reluctance to have them return so soon. Mr. Bingley and his sister express their desire for the sisters to stay longer.
402-444.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane decide to leave Netherfield and communicate this to their hosts. There is a discussion about the safety and timing of their departure, with some persuasion from Mr. Bingley and his sister for them to stay longer.
text_phrases: carriage might be sent for them
their original design of leaving Netherfield

402-444.description: At breakfast, Mr. Bennet teases his family about expecting a new guest, revealing it to be Mr. Collins. He shares the contents of a letter from Mr. Collins, who is to inherit the family estate, causing distress to Mrs. Bennet.
402-444.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet announces a new guest, Mr. Collins, to his curious family. Mrs. Bennet expresses her displeasure about the entailment of their estate to Mr. Collins.
text_phrases: expect an addition to our family party
explaining the nature of an entail

444-477.description: Mr. Collins writes a letter to Mr. Bennet expressing his desire to mend their relationship and extend an olive branch, influenced by his patroness Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
444-477.location: Bennet's residence, Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent
444-477.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins writes about his intentions to heal the breach with Mr. Bennet, influenced by his ordination and the patronage of Lady Catherine. He mentions his hopes to visit and extend goodwill.
text_phrases: distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh

444-477.description: Mr. Collins arrives at the Bennet's residence and engages in conversation during dinner, praising the family and expressing his intentions.
444-477.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins compliments the Bennet family, particularly praising the daughters and discussing the entail of the estate. He apologizes for any displeasure and is corrected by Mrs. Bennet about the cookery.
text_phrases: complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of daughters
dinner too in its turn was highly admired

444-477.description: After dinner, Mr. Bennet engages Mr. Collins in a conversation about Lady Catherine de Bourgh, where Mr. Collins praises her extensively.
444-477.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins speaks highly of Lady Catherine's affability and condescension, recounting his positive experiences and her advice on his personal matters.
text_phrases: suggested some shelves in the closets upstairs

478-496.description: During tea time at the Bennet's home, Mr. Collins chooses to read Fordyce's Sermons to the ladies, but Lydia interrupts with news about her uncle. Mr. Collins, offended by the lack of interest in serious literature, ceases reading and opts to play backgammon with Mr. Bennet instead.
478-496.dialog_summary: Lydia interrupts Mr. Collins's reading with family news, leading to Mr. Collins expressing disappointment in the young ladies' disinterest in serious books. He then shifts to playing backgammon with Mr. Bennet.
text_phrases: Lydia gaped as he opened the volume

478-496.scene_title: Meryton Walk and Mr. Wickham's Introduction
478-496.description: The Bennet sisters, along with Mr. Collins, walk to Meryton where they encounter Mr. Denny and a new, charming gentleman, Mr. Wickham. The introduction leads to a noticeable tension between Mr. Wickham and Mr. Darcy when they cross paths.
478-496.dialog_summary: Mr. Denny introduces Mr. Wickham to the Bennet sisters. Tension arises when Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley arrive, leading to a strained greeting between Mr. Darcy and Mr. Wickham.
text_phrases: led the way across the street

497-533.description: Mr. Collins and his cousins are conveyed by coach to Meryton where they enter a drawing-room and learn that Mr. Wickham is present.
text_phrases: the size and furniture of the apartment
indifferent imitations of china on the mantle-piece

497-533.description: During a social gathering, Elizabeth Bennet engages in a conversation with Mr. Wickham, who shares details about his past and his connections with Mr. Darcy.
497-533.dialog_summary: Mr. Wickham discusses his past, his grievances against Mr. Darcy, and his lost opportunities due to Mr. Darcy's actions. Elizabeth expresses shock and sympathy.
text_phrases: Mr. Wickham walked into the room
Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before
Mr. Wickham began the subject himself
Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase

534-568.description: Elizabeth and Wickham discuss Mr. Darcy's character, focusing on his pride and its impact on his actions.
534-568.location: A room in the Philips' residence
534-568.dialog_summary: Wickham describes Mr. Darcy's pride as both a flaw and a virtue, influencing him to act generously at times. Elizabeth is surprised and questions how Mr. Darcy's pride could be seen positively.

534-568.scene_title: Whist Party and Discussion with Mr. Collins
534-568.description: After a whist party, Elizabeth and Mr. Collins discuss Lady Catherine de Bourgh and her connections, while Mr. Wickham inquires about Mr. Collins' relationship with the de Bourgh family.
534-568.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins downplays his losses at whist, attributing his indifference to Lady Catherine's patronage. Wickham and Elizabeth discuss Lady Catherine's influence and connections.
text_phrases: whist party soon afterwards breaking up
players gathered round the other table

534-568.description: The Bingley siblings visit the Bennet family to personally invite them to the upcoming ball at Netherfield.
534-568.dialog_summary: The Bingley siblings express their eagerness for the Bennet family to attend the ball, while avoiding much interaction with Mrs. Bennet.
text_phrases: personal invitation for the long expected ball

569-603.scene_title: Elizabeth and Mr. Collins at the Ball
569-603.description: Elizabeth is surprised by Mr. Collins' willingness to dance and his forwardness in asking her for the first two dances, despite her plans to dance with Mr. Wickham.
569-603.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins expresses his enthusiasm for dancing and solicits Elizabeth for the first two dances, which surprises her as she had intended to dance with Mr. Wickham.

569-603.description: At the Netherfield ball, Elizabeth looks for Mr. Wickham but finds out from Mr. Denny that he had to leave town, which disappoints her greatly.
569-603.dialog_summary: Mr. Denny informs Elizabeth that Mr. Wickham had to leave town on business, hinting that he wanted to avoid Mr. Darcy.

569-603.scene_title: Dance and Dialogue with Mr. Darcy
569-603.description: Elizabeth unexpectedly accepts to dance with Mr. Darcy and they engage in a conversation where they discuss their views and personalities.
569-603.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy discuss their taciturn dispositions and views on conversation during dancing, leading to a strained but revealing dialogue.

604-636.description: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy engage in a probing conversation during a dance, where Elizabeth tries to decipher Darcy's character through his responses to her pointed questions.
604-636.dialog_summary: Elizabeth questions Darcy's ability to forgive and avoid prejudice, to which Darcy responds cautiously. Elizabeth expresses confusion about Darcy's character due to varying reports about him.
text_phrases: The present always occupies you in such scenes

604-636.description: Miss Bingley confronts Elizabeth with disdain about her admiration for Mr. Wickham, revealing his true relation to Mr. Darcy and questioning his credibility.
604-636.dialog_summary: Miss Bingley accuses Wickham of dishonesty and defends Mr. Darcy's treatment of him, while Elizabeth counters her accusations, defending Wickham.
text_phrases: with an expression of civil disdain

604-636.description: Elizabeth seeks Jane's opinion on Mr. Wickham, but Jane has nothing conclusive to report, relying on Mr. Bingley's limited knowledge.
604-636.dialog_summary: Elizabeth inquires about Wickham, and Jane shares that Bingley is unaware of the full story but trusts Darcy's judgment, which disappoints Elizabeth.
text_phrases: Jane met her with a smile

604-636.description: Mr. Collins attempts to introduce himself to Mr. Darcy, believing it his duty due to a perceived connection through Lady Catherine, despite Elizabeth's protests.
604-636.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins insists on introducing himself to Mr. Darcy, citing his clerical duty and ignoring Elizabeth's advice against it. The encounter is awkward and ends with Darcy's distant civility.
text_phrases: Mr. Collins came up to them
Mr. Darcy was eyeing him with unrestrained wonder

637-660.description: During a dinner party, Elizabeth Bennet experiences embarrassment due to her mother's loud comments and her sister Mary's singing. Mr. Collins makes a long speech about his duties as a clergyman.
637-660.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet speaks indiscreetly, causing Elizabeth distress. Mary sings despite Elizabeth's silent pleas not to. Mr. Collins delivers a lengthy speech about his responsibilities and virtues as a clergyman.

637-660.description: Mr. Collins prepares to make a formal marriage proposal to Elizabeth Bennet and requests a private audience with her after breakfast.
637-660.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins requests Mrs. Bennet's permission to speak privately with Elizabeth, which Mrs. Bennet grants enthusiastically despite Elizabeth's reluctance.

661-692.description: Mr. Collins proposes marriage to Elizabeth, listing various reasons including advice from Lady Catherine. Elizabeth declines his proposal firmly, leading to a discussion where Mr. Collins misunderstands her refusal as modesty or playing hard to get.
661-692.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, citing reasons and advice from Lady Catherine. Elizabeth declines the proposal, but Mr. Collins persists, misunderstanding her refusal.
text_phrases: Mrs. Jenkinson was arranging Miss de Bourgh's foot-stool

661-692.description: Following Elizabeth's refusal, Mr. Collins and Mrs. Bennet discuss the situation. Mrs. Bennet is determined to make Elizabeth accept the proposal, while Mr. Bennet remains indifferent.
661-692.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet tries to convince Mr. Collins that Elizabeth will be persuaded, while Mr. Bennet shows indifference. Elizabeth is summoned to discuss the matter further.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule
called out as she entered the library

693-720.description: Mr. Bennet presents Elizabeth with a difficult choice regarding her marriage to Mr. Collins, leading to a heated discussion with Mrs. Bennet.
693-720.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet tells Elizabeth she must choose between her parents depending on her decision about marrying Mr. Collins. Mrs. Bennet is upset and insists Elizabeth should marry him.
text_phrases: be a stranger to one of your parents

693-720.description: Charlotte Lucas visits the Bennet family and learns about Elizabeth's refusal to marry Mr. Collins, leading to further discussions and Mrs. Bennet's complaints.
693-720.dialog_summary: Lydia and Kitty inform Charlotte about Elizabeth's refusal to marry Mr. Collins. Mrs. Bennet tries to persuade Charlotte to convince Elizabeth while complaining about her situation.

693-720.description: In a conversation with Mrs. Bennet, Mr. Collins formally withdraws his marriage proposal to Elizabeth, expressing his resignation and lack of regret.
693-720.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins tells Mrs. Bennet he is withdrawing his proposal and does not resent Elizabeth's refusal. He apologizes if his manner was objectionable.
text_phrases: let Mr. Collins and me have a little conversation

721-747.scene_title: Jane and Elizabeth Discuss Caroline Bingley's Intentions
721-747.description: Jane and Elizabeth Bennet discuss a letter from Caroline Bingley, interpreting her intentions regarding Mr. Bingley and Miss Darcy. Elizabeth tries to convince Jane of Caroline's manipulative nature, while Jane maintains a more naive view, hoping Caroline is merely deceived.
721-747.dialog_summary: Elizabeth interprets Caroline Bingley's letter as manipulative, aiming to separate Jane from Mr. Bingley and match him with Miss Darcy. Jane hopes Caroline is just deceived, not deceitful.

721-747.scene_title: Mr. Collins Proposes to Charlotte Lucas
721-747.description: Mr. Collins proposes to Charlotte Lucas, who accepts his proposal not out of love but for the security of marriage. The scene captures Mr. Collins's awkwardness and Charlotte's pragmatic acceptance.
721-747.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins proposes to Charlotte Lucas, who accepts him for the prospect of marriage rather than romantic affection.
text_phrases: perceived him from an upper window

748-774.description: Sir William Lucas visits the Bennet family to announce Charlotte's engagement to Mr. Collins, which is met with incredulity and protest from the Bennet family.
748-774.location: The Bennet's living room at Longbourn
748-774.dialog_summary: Sir William announces Charlotte's engagement, Mrs. Bennet and Lydia express disbelief and protest, Elizabeth confirms the news, and Sir William handles the situation with courtesy.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested

748-774.description: After the announcement, Elizabeth reflects on Charlotte's decision to marry Mr. Collins, feeling disappointed and concerned about her friend's happiness.
748-774.dialog_summary: Elizabeth internally debates Charlotte's decision, feeling it was a sacrifice for worldly advantage, and struggles to reconcile with the idea of the match.
text_phrases: Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard
Charlotte the wife of Mr. Collins, was a most humiliating picture!

775-821.description: Mrs. Bennet expresses her dismay about Charlotte Lucas becoming the mistress of their house, and Mr. Bennet tries to console her with a hope for better things.
775-821.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet is upset about Charlotte Lucas taking over their estate due to the entail and expresses her frustration. Mr. Bennet responds with a philosophical and consoling remark hoping he might outlive the entail.

775-821.description: Jane receives a letter from Miss Bingley confirming their stay in London and expressing regret for not visiting Hertfordshire. Jane and Elizabeth discuss the implications of the letter.
775-821.dialog_summary: Jane is disheartened by the letter from Miss Bingley, which confirms that Bingley and his party are settled in London. Elizabeth listens to Jane's concerns with a mix of concern and indignation towards Bingley and his sisters.
text_phrases: settled in London for the winter
regret at not having had time to pay his respects

775-821.description: Elizabeth and Jane discuss Mr. Bingley's actions and the influence of his sisters and friends on his decisions regarding Jane.
775-821.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane debate the reasons behind Bingley's behavior and the potential influence of his sisters and Mr. Darcy. Jane hopes for the best, while Elizabeth expresses skepticism and concern for Jane's feelings.

822-850.description: Mr. Wickham's presence helps alleviate the gloom for the Longbourn family due to recent upsetting events. His openness about his past with Mr. Darcy changes public opinion about Darcy.
Upon the arrival of Mrs. Bennet's brother and his wife for Christmas, Mrs. Bennet shares her grievances about her daughters' failed marriage prospects and criticizes her neighbors.
822-850.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet complains about her daughters' failed engagements and criticizes the Lucases and Mr. Darcy.
text_phrases: receiving her brother and his wife

822-850.description: Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner discuss Mr. Bingley's inconstant affections towards Jane, and Mrs. Gardiner advises Elizabeth about the imprudence of an attachment with Mr. Wickham.
822-850.dialog_summary: Mrs. Gardiner advises Elizabeth to be cautious about forming an imprudent attachment with Mr. Wickham, despite his agreeable nature.

851-875.description: Elizabeth and Charlotte discuss future visits and correspondence as Charlotte prepares to leave after her wedding.
851-875.dialog_summary: Charlotte asks Elizabeth to visit her in Kent and to keep in touch frequently. Elizabeth agrees, though she anticipates little pleasure from the visit.
text_phrases: Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother's ungracious and reluctant good wishes

851-875.description: Jane writes to Elizabeth about her uneventful encounter with Caroline Bingley in London, expressing her disappointment and suspicions.
851-875.dialog_summary: Jane recounts her visit to Caroline Bingley, noting Caroline's lack of enthusiasm and altered behavior, leading Jane to resolve to end the acquaintance.
text_phrases: Jane had been a week in town
Jane wrote again when the visit was paid

851-875.scene_title: Elizabeth Reflects on Mr. Bingley's Indifference
851-875.description: Elizabeth ponders over Jane's situation with Mr. Bingley and his apparent indifference, as relayed through Jane's letters.
851-875.dialog_summary: Elizabeth reads Jane's letters and reflects on Mr. Bingley's lack of attention towards Jane, feeling a mix of disappointment and resignation.
text_phrases: Elizabeth shook her head over this letter
Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him

876-906.description: Elizabeth bids farewell to her father and Mr. Wickham before embarking on a journey with Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria. They travel to Gracechurch-street, arriving by noon.
876-906.dialog_summary: Elizabeth's father expresses his reluctance for her departure and asks her to write. Mr. Wickham and Elizabeth exchange friendly farewells, reflecting on their past interactions.
text_phrases: The only pain was in leaving her father
The farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham
they began it so early as to be in Gracechurch-street by noon

876-906.scene_title: Arrival at the Gardiner's and Evening Plans
876-906.description: Upon arriving at Mr. Gardiner's, Elizabeth is warmly greeted by her family. The day is spent in shopping and attending a theatre in the evening.
876-906.location: Mr. Gardiner's house and a theatre
876-906.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and her family enjoy a pleasant day together, shopping and later going to the theatre.
text_phrases: Jane was at a drawing-room window
the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls
the evening at one of the theatres

876-906.description: Elizabeth discusses with her aunt Mrs. Gardiner about Mr. Wickham's recent actions and Miss King's situation, reflecting on the motives behind matrimonial choices.
876-906.dialog_summary: Mrs. Gardiner questions Wickham's intentions towards Miss King, leading to a discussion on the difference between mercenary and prudent matrimonial motives. Elizabeth expresses her disillusionment with men.
text_phrases: Mrs. Gardiner gave her the particulars
Mrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham's desertion
Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt

907-937.description: Elizabeth spends the evening reflecting on Charlotte's contentment with her marriage, anticipating her visit, and considering the interruptions from Mr. Collins and the interactions with Rosings.
text_phrases: in the solitude of her chamber
meditate upon Charlotte's degree of contentment

907-937.description: Elizabeth is interrupted by Maria while preparing for a walk. Maria urgently calls her downstairs to witness an unexpected sight.
907-937.dialog_summary: Maria urgently tells Elizabeth to come downstairs to see an unexpected sight, but refuses to reveal what it is.
text_phrases: in her room getting ready for a walk

907-937.description: Elizabeth and Maria discover that the cause of the commotion is Lady Catherine and Miss De Bourgh stopping at their garden gate.
907-937.dialog_summary: Elizabeth initially mistakes the visitors for an intrusion by pigs into the garden, but Maria corrects her, identifying the visitors as Mrs. Jenkinson and Miss De Bourgh.
text_phrases: two ladies stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate

907-937.description: Mr. Collins excitedly shares the news of an invitation to dine at Rosings, expressing his anticipation of displaying the grandeur of his patroness.
907-937.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins shares the news of the dinner invitation at Rosings and expresses his excitement about it. Sir William comments on the expected behavior of the upper class.
text_phrases: Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two girls
the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day

938-970.scene_title: Discussion on Education and Social Etiquette
938-970.description: Lady Catherine and Elizabeth Bennet engage in a conversation about the upbringing and education of the Bennet sisters, particularly focusing on the absence of a governess and the social implications of all the Bennet sisters being 'out' in society.
938-970.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine expresses surprise and disapproval about the Bennet sisters not having a governess and all being out in society simultaneously. Elizabeth defends their education and the decision to have all sisters out.

938-970.description: A card game session takes place at Rosings with Lady Catherine, Sir William, Mr. and Mrs. Collins, and Miss De Bourgh among others. The session is filled with minimal conversation unrelated to the game, and Lady Catherine dominates the discussion.
938-970.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine leads the conversation, mostly correcting others or sharing anecdotes about herself. Mr. Collins agrees with everything Lady Catherine says.

938-970.description: After a social gathering at Rosings, the guests prepare to leave. Lady Catherine offers the carriage to Mrs. Collins, who accepts it gratefully. The departure is marked by formalities and expressions of gratitude.
938-970.dialog_summary: The guests express their thanks and take leave from Rosings with formal goodbyes and the carriage is prepared for Mrs. Collins.

971-1012.scene_title: Conversation in Lady Catherine's Drawing Room
971-1012.description: Elizabeth, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and others are gathered in Lady Catherine's drawing room. Colonel Fitzwilliam engages Elizabeth in a lively conversation about music and travel, drawing the attention of Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy.
971-1012.location: Lady Catherine's drawing room at Rosings
971-1012.dialog_summary: Colonel Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth discuss various topics including music and travel, catching the interest of Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy. Lady Catherine interjects, wanting to be included in the conversation about music, and later critiques Elizabeth's piano playing.
text_phrases: sat down directly to the instrument
moving with his usual deliberation towards the piano-forte

971-1012.description: Elizabeth is surprised by a visit from Mr. Darcy while she is alone at home, writing to Jane. They engage in a conversation about Mr. Bingley's sudden departure from Netherfield.
971-1012.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy explains his unexpected visit and discusses Mr. Bingley's future plans concerning Netherfield, suggesting that Bingley may not spend much time there anymore.
text_phrases: startled by a ring at the door
Mr. Darcy only, entered the room

1013-1055.description: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy engage in a conversation about Mr. Collins and his marriage, discussing the practicalities and personal opinions on the matter.
1013-1055.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth discuss Mr. Collins's marriage, the comfort of the house, and the distance from Elizabeth's family. The conversation shifts to personal opinions on marriage and distance, ending with Mr. Darcy's inquiry about Elizabeth's attachment to Hertfordshire.
text_phrases: This seems a very comfortable house.
Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.
drew his chair a little towards her
took a newspaper from the table

1013-1055.description: Elizabeth unexpectedly meets Mr. Darcy during her walks in the park, leading to awkward conversations and silent companionship.
1013-1055.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy have brief, awkward conversations during unexpected meetings in the park, discussing her stay at Hunsford and her opinions on Mr. and Mrs. Collins's happiness.

1013-1055.description: Elizabeth and Colonel Fitzwilliam discuss his life as a younger son, the financial necessities of marriage, and Mr. Darcy's character.
1013-1055.dialog_summary: Colonel Fitzwilliam explains the financial constraints of being a younger son and discusses Mr. Darcy's preferences and habits. Elizabeth questions the value of a younger son in jest.
text_phrases: making the tour of the Park

1056-1088.description: Elizabeth and Colonel Fitzwilliam discuss Mr. Darcy's interference in Mr. Bingley's romantic affairs, leading to Elizabeth's growing indignation.
1056-1088.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Fitzwilliam discuss Mr. Darcy's influence over Mr. Bingley, including Darcy's interference in Bingley's potential marriage. Elizabeth expresses her disapproval of Darcy's actions.
text_phrases: Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on
Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful
abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters

1056-1088.description: Elizabeth reflects on the conversation with Fitzwilliam, feeling agitated and attributing Mr. Bingley's separation from Jane to Mr. Darcy's influence.
1056-1088.dialog_summary: Elizabeth thinks about Mr. Darcy's role in separating Mr. Bingley from Jane, feeling distressed and attributing the principal design to Mr. Darcy.
text_phrases: think without interruption of all that she had heard

1056-1088.description: Mr. Darcy visits Elizabeth unexpectedly and confesses his love for her, leading to a tense and emotional conversation.
1056-1088.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy confesses his love to Elizabeth, who is astonished and conflicted. She rejects his proposal, citing his interference in her sister's happiness and his pride.
text_phrases: Mr. Darcy walk into the room
sat down for a few moments
getting up walked about the room

1089-1116.scene_title: Heated Confrontation Between Elizabeth and Darcy
1089-1116.description: Elizabeth confronts Darcy about his actions that led to the separation of Jane and Bingley, as well as his treatment of Wickham. Darcy responds with a mixture of justification and contempt, leading to a tense exchange of accusations and personal reflections.
1089-1116.dialog_summary: Elizabeth accuses Darcy of causing misery by separating Jane and Bingley and mistreating Wickham. Darcy admits his actions but defends them. Elizabeth expresses her longstanding disapproval of Darcy, which he acknowledges with a mixture of regret and justification.
text_phrases: he was listening with an air
he even looked at her with a smile
walked with quick steps across the room
open the front door and quit the house

1089-1116.description: After a tumultuous confrontation, Elizabeth reflects on the surprising marriage proposal from Darcy. Later, during a walk, Darcy unexpectedly meets her and hands her a letter, explaining his actions and feelings in detail.
1089-1116.dialog_summary: Darcy encounters Elizabeth during her walk, hands her a letter explaining his past actions and feelings, and leaves promptly.
text_phrases: proceeding directly to her favourite walk
stop at the gates and look into the park

1117-1125.description: In this scene, Mr. Darcy writes a detailed letter to Elizabeth Bennet explaining his past actions and decisions, particularly concerning Mr. Wickham and Elizabeth's sister, Georgiana. He reveals the true nature of Wickham's character and his own reasons for his actions.
1117-1125.dialog_summary: Darcy explains his past actions in a letter, detailing his interactions with Wickham and his efforts to protect his sister Georgiana from an elopement. He also addresses his role in influencing Bingley's decision regarding Jane Bennet.
text_phrases: Mr. Darcy gave her the letter

1126-1149.description: Elizabeth reflects on her past interactions with Wickham and Darcy, realizing her own prejudices and misjudgments.
1126-1149.dialog_summary: Elizabeth internally debates and reflects on her previous judgments and conversations regarding Wickham and Darcy, realizing her own follies and biases.

1126-1149.description: Lady Catherine de Bourgh invites Elizabeth to extend her stay, which Elizabeth politely declines.
1126-1149.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine expresses her desire for Elizabeth to stay longer at Rosings, but Elizabeth insists on returning home due to her father's request. Lady Catherine then suggests sending a servant with Elizabeth for safety.

1150-1182.description: Lady Catherine inquires about Elizabeth and Maria's journey plans, gives them packing advice, and wishes them a good journey.
1150-1182.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine asks about the journey, gives packing advice, and wishes Elizabeth and Maria a good journey.
text_phrases: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask
gave them directions as to the best method of packing
Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the work of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh

1150-1182.description: Mr. Collins expresses his gratitude to Elizabeth for her visit and assures her of the value of their connection with Lady Catherine.
1150-1182.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins thanks Elizabeth for her visit and praises their connection with Lady Catherine, while Elizabeth responds politely.
text_phrases: Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast
he took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities
Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room

1150-1182.description: Elizabeth and Maria prepare to leave Hunsford, with Mr. Collins seeing them off. They briefly forget to leave a message for the ladies of Rosings.
1150-1182.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins bids farewell to Elizabeth and Maria, reminds them to send regards to the ladies of Rosings, and they depart in a carriage.
text_phrases: the trunks were fastened on, the parcels placed within, and it was pronounced to be ready
Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by Mr. Collins

1183-1222.description: Lydia shares news about Wickham and Mary King while the family sits down to eat. Elizabeth and Jane react to the news, and the waiter is dismissed from the room.
1183-1222.dialog_summary: Lydia reveals that Mary King has moved to Liverpool, removing the danger of her marrying Wickham. The sisters discuss the implications and express relief.
text_phrases: waiter was told that he need not stay

1183-1222.description: The Bennet sisters and their party are crammed into a carriage, discussing their experiences and joking as they travel back home.
1183-1222.dialog_summary: Lydia talks about her purchases and the fun they had, while encouraging everyone to share their stories. The sisters engage in light-hearted conversation.
text_phrases: talk and laugh all the way home

1183-1222.description: The Bennet family, along with the Lucases, gather in the dining room where various conversations take place about recent events and personal updates.
1183-1222.location: Dining room at the Bennet's house
1183-1222.dialog_summary: The group discusses various topics including fashion, recent fun, and personal updates. Lydia dominates the conversation with her loud recounting of the day's events.

1223-1259.description: Elizabeth and Jane Bennet discuss the character of Mr. Wickham and the implications of making his true nature known to others. They talk about the potential consequences and decide on keeping the information private.
1223-1259.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane discuss whether to expose Wickham's true character to others. They conclude it's best to keep it private as exposing him could have severe repercussions.

1223-1259.scene_title: Mrs. Bennet Discusses Jane's Sad Business
1223-1259.description: Mrs. Bennet expresses her resolution to never speak of Jane's unfortunate love affair again, revealing her frustration and resignation about the situation.
1223-1259.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet declares she will no longer discuss Jane's failed relationship and expresses skepticism about Jane's chances with Mr. Bingley.
text_phrases: what is your opinion now of this sad business of Jane's?

1223-1259.description: Lydia Bennet receives an invitation to go to Brighton with Mrs. Forster, causing excitement and envy within the Bennet household.
1223-1259.dialog_summary: Lydia is ecstatic about her invitation to Brighton, while Kitty is envious. Elizabeth and Jane try to reason with Kitty.
text_phrases: Lydia flew about the house in restless ecstacy
laughing and talking with more violence than ever

1260-1286.description: Lydia imagines her delightful prospects at Brighton, filled with officers and social activities, while Elizabeth reflects on her disappointing interactions with Mr. Wickham, feeling disillusioned by his renewed attentions.
1260-1286.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Wickham discuss Mr. Darcy, with Wickham expressing skepticism about Darcy's improvements and Elizabeth clarifying her views on Darcy's character.
text_phrases: streets of that gay bathing place

1260-1286.description: Lydia leaves for Brighton with Mrs. Forster, amidst a mix of loud farewells and Kitty's tears. Elizabeth reflects on her family dynamics and the consequences of her parents' mismatched marriage.
1260-1286.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet expresses loud good wishes for Lydia, overshadowing the more gentle farewells from her sisters.
text_phrases: separation between her and her family

1287-1335.description: The Gardiners have to delay their northern tour due to Mr. Gardiner's business commitments, leading them to adjust their travel plans to a more limited tour in Derbyshire instead of the Lakes.
1287-1335.dialog_summary: Mrs. Gardiner's letter explains the change in plans due to Mr. Gardiner's business commitments.
text_phrases: a letter arrived from Mrs. Gardiner
Mr. Gardiner would be prevented by business

1287-1335.scene_title: Arrival of the Gardiners at Longbourn
1287-1335.description: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner arrive at Longbourn with their children, who are to be cared for by their cousin Jane.
1287-1335.dialog_summary: The Gardiners discuss their travel adjustments and their stay at Longbourn.
text_phrases: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at Longbourn
The Gardiners staid only one night at Longbourn

1287-1335.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners discuss visiting Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy, despite Elizabeth's initial reluctance.
1287-1335.dialog_summary: Mrs. Gardiner expresses a desire to visit Pemberley again, and Elizabeth reluctantly agrees after ensuring Mr. Darcy is not present.
text_phrases: In talking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed an inclination to see the place again
Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation

1287-1335.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners arrive at Pemberley, and Elizabeth is struck by the beauty of the estate as they approach.
text_phrases: they turned in at the lodge
drove for some time through a beautiful wood
the eye was instantly caught by Pemberley House

1287-1335.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners tour the interior of Pemberley, admiring its elegance and the views it offers.
1287-1335.dialog_summary: The housekeeper introduces the Gardiners and Elizabeth to Pemberley's interior and shares details about Mr. Darcy and his sister.
text_phrases: They followed her into the dining-parlour
Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect

1336-1365.scene_title: Praise of Mr. Darcy by the Housekeeper
1336-1365.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners are touring Pemberley and listening to the housekeeper, Mrs. Reynolds, who praises Mr. Darcy extensively. Elizabeth is surprised by the positive description, contrasting with her previous opinion of him.
1336-1365.dialog_summary: Mrs. Reynolds praises Mr. Darcy's character, describing him as a good master and a kind person, which surprises Elizabeth given her prior judgment of him.

1336-1365.description: While walking across the lawn at Pemberley, Elizabeth and the Gardiners unexpectedly encounter Mr. Darcy. The meeting is awkward, with evident surprise and embarrassment on both sides.
1336-1365.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth exchange greetings with a marked change in Mr. Darcy's demeanor, showing civility and gentleness, which confuses Elizabeth.

1366-1389.description: Elizabeth begins to admire the beauty of Pemberley but stops short due to past recollections. Mr. Darcy surprises her by seeking an introduction to her friends, whom he previously disdained.
1366-1389.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is surprised by Mr. Darcy's polite request for an introduction to her friends. She reflects on his changed behavior.
text_phrases: admire the beauty of the place
descending to the brink of the river

1366-1389.description: During a walk, Mr. Darcy invites Mr. Gardiner to fish in his streams and offers him fishing tackle. Elizabeth is internally conflicted about Mr. Darcy's altered demeanor towards her.
1366-1389.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy invites Mr. Gardiner to fish and offers equipment. Elizabeth ponders why Mr. Darcy has become so amiable.
text_phrases: talk of Matlock and Dove Dale

1366-1389.description: Mr. Darcy expresses his wish to introduce his sister, Miss Darcy, to Elizabeth during her stay at Lambton, surprising Elizabeth.
1366-1389.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy asks Elizabeth if he can introduce his sister to her, which surprises Elizabeth.
text_phrases: handing the ladies into the carriage

1390-1406.description: Elizabeth meets Miss Darcy, who is described as tall, graceful, and womanly. Elizabeth is relieved to find Miss Darcy gentle and unassuming, contrasting with her expectations of encountering someone as observant as Mr. Darcy.
1390-1406.dialog_summary: Elizabeth internally reflects on Miss Darcy's demeanor, finding her gentle and unassuming.

1390-1406.description: Bingley arrives unexpectedly and engages in a friendly conversation with Elizabeth, inquiring about her family and expressing his pleasure at seeing her again.
1390-1406.dialog_summary: Bingley expresses his pleasure at seeing Elizabeth again and inquires about her family in a friendly manner.
text_phrases: Bingley's quick step was heard on the stairs

1390-1406.description: Mr. Darcy extends an invitation to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Miss Bennet for dinner at Pemberley, which is accepted after some hesitation from Elizabeth.
1390-1406.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy invites the Gardiners and Miss Bennet to dinner, which is accepted by Mrs. Gardiner after observing Elizabeth's reaction.
text_phrases: Mr. Darcy called on his sister
Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece

1407-1427.description: Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner are received by Miss Darcy, Mrs. Hurst, and Miss Bingley in a room where they experience an awkward reception and conversation.
1407-1427.dialog_summary: Initial awkward reception followed by a forced conversation led by Mrs. Annesley, with occasional contributions from Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner. Miss Darcy appears shy and reserved.

1407-1427.description: During a visit, the entrance of servants with refreshments slightly eases the tension, leading to a gathering around the table. However, the underlying tensions and personal dynamics continue to affect the interactions.
1407-1427.dialog_summary: Servants bring in food which gathers everyone at the table. Miss Bingley makes a snide remark to Elizabeth about the militia, which Elizabeth counters calmly.
text_phrases: cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits
beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches
Elizabeth answered with equal indifference and brevity

1407-1427.description: Mr. Darcy enters the room, causing a shift in the atmosphere as everyone's attention turns towards him. Elizabeth and Miss Bingley have a tense exchange in his presence.
1407-1427.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Miss Bingley exchange words in a tense atmosphere heightened by Mr. Darcy's presence. Miss Bingley tries to unsettle Elizabeth by mentioning Wickham indirectly.
text_phrases: Miss Bingley makes a snide remark

1428-1449.description: Elizabeth reads a distressing letter from her sister Jane, revealing the elopement of their youngest sister Lydia with Mr. Wickham, and the family's unsuccessful attempts to locate them.
1428-1449.dialog_summary: Elizabeth reads aloud parts of Jane's letter, expressing concern and detailing the events following Lydia's elopement. Mr. Darcy enters and expresses his concern, offering help and trying to comfort Elizabeth.
text_phrases: opening it with the utmost impatience
it was opened by a servant
she sat down, unable to support herself
Darcy was walking up and down the room
covering her face with her handkerchief
Elizabeth was soon lost to every thing else
He readily assured her of his secrecy

1450-1478.description: Elizabeth, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner discuss the sudden illness of their niece and the urgent need to address Lydia's situation. They read letters aloud, express their concerns, and plan their immediate departure.
1450-1478.dialog_summary: The Gardiners express deep concern over Lydia's situation, read letters detailing the issues, and discuss plans to assist. Elizabeth thanks Mr. Gardiner for his support.

1450-1478.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners discuss the implications of Lydia's actions and Wickham's character as they travel urgently back to Longbourn.
1450-1478.location: Carriage on the road to Longbourn
1450-1478.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and the Gardiners debate Wickham's intentions and Lydia's understanding, expressing doubts and hopes about the situation.

1450-1478.description: Elizabeth and the Gardiners arrive at Longbourn, greeted by the little Gardiners and Jane. Elizabeth quickly seeks updates on the fugitives.
1450-1478.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane reunite with an emotional embrace and immediately discuss the situation concerning Lydia and the fugitives.
text_phrases: standing on the steps of the house
carriage drove up to the door
running down stairs from her mother's apartment

1479-1516.description: Jane and Elizabeth Bennet discuss the well-being of their family members and the recent events concerning Lydia's elopement. The scene takes place in the drawing room where the family gathers and expresses their concerns and hopes.
1479-1516.dialog_summary: Jane and Elizabeth discuss the health and spirits of their mother and siblings, and the recent troubling events concerning Lydia. The family hopes for good news soon.

1479-1516.description: Mrs. Bennet expresses her distress and blames others for Lydia's elopement, while Mr. Gardiner tries to calm her and promises to help in recovering Lydia.
1479-1516.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet laments Lydia's elopement and blames everyone except herself. Mr. Gardiner assures her of his support and plans to go to London to assist Mr. Bennet.

1479-1516.description: The Bennet sisters, along with Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, discuss Lydia's elopement and its implications while dining. Mary and Kitty join later, each coming from their own engagements.
1479-1516.dialog_summary: The family discusses Lydia's elopement and its potential consequences. Mary offers moral reflections, while Elizabeth and Jane express their concerns and seek more information.

1517-1541.description: Elizabeth expresses shock and dismay after reading Lydia's letter, reflecting on the seriousness of Lydia's actions and the impact on their father.
1517-1541.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is upset by Lydia's thoughtlessness as expressed in her letter and worries about the effect on their father.

1517-1541.description: The Bennet family is in disarray after the news of Lydia's elopement, with Mr. Bennet shocked into silence, Mrs. Bennet falling ill, and the household in confusion.
1517-1541.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane discuss the shock and illness that has befallen their parents and the confusion in the household.
text_phrases: He could not speak a word

1517-1541.description: Mr. Bennet travels to Epsom and Clapham to track down Lydia and Wickham, making inquiries about the hackney coach they used.
1517-1541.dialog_summary: Jane recounts Mr. Bennet's efforts to trace Lydia and Wickham through the hackney coach they used and his plans to continue his inquiries in London.
text_phrases: discover the number of the hackney coach

1517-1541.description: Mr. Collins sends a letter to Mr. Bennet, offering condolences for Lydia's actions and reflecting on the impact on the family's reputation.
1517-1541.dialog_summary: Mr. Collins expresses sympathy for Mr. Bennet's distress over Lydia's behavior and advises him to disown her, highlighting the damage to the family's reputation.

1542-1602.scene_title: Mr. Bennet's Return and Family Concerns
1542-1602.description: Mr. Bennet returns home after an unsuccessful attempt to find Lydia and Wickham in London. His return brings mixed reactions from the family, and he discusses the situation with Elizabeth and Jane.
1542-1602.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane discuss with Mr. Bennet about the letter from Mr. Gardiner regarding Lydia's situation. Mr. Bennet expresses his reluctance to deal with the situation but acknowledges it must be done.
text_phrases: Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject
went to the library to write

1542-1602.description: Jane and Elizabeth receive unexpected news from Mrs. Hill about an express letter from Mr. Gardiner concerning Lydia, leading to a hurried search for Mr. Bennet around the estate.
1542-1602.dialog_summary: Mrs. Hill informs Jane and Elizabeth about an express letter from Mr. Gardiner. The sisters urgently seek Mr. Bennet to discuss the contents of the letter.
text_phrases: ran through the vestibule into the breakfast room
ran across the lawn after their father

1603-1629.description: Elizabeth and Jane discuss the financial arrangements made by Mr. Gardiner for Lydia's marriage and their gratitude towards him. They also talk about forgetting past grievances for future happiness.
1603-1629.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane discuss the debts of Wickham, the financial help from Mr. Gardiner, and the need to forget past issues for future happiness.

1603-1629.description: The Bennet sisters consult their father about informing their mother of Lydia's situation. Mr. Bennet responds indifferently while writing at his desk.
1603-1629.dialog_summary: The sisters ask Mr. Bennet if they should inform their mother about Lydia; he responds indifferently.

1603-1629.scene_title: Joyful News in the Living Room
1603-1629.description: Mrs. Bennet reacts with overwhelming joy upon hearing the news of Lydia's impending marriage, read by Jane from Mr. Gardiner's letter.
1603-1629.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet expresses extreme joy about Lydia's marriage news, discussed by Jane and Elizabeth.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself

1603-1629.description: Mrs. Bennet plans to inform the neighborhood and arrange for Lydia's wedding clothes, while expressing her happiness and making plans for visiting Meryton.
1603-1629.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet plans to share the good news with relatives and arranges for Lydia's wedding preparations.
text_phrases: I will write to my sister Gardiner

1630-1655.description: Elizabeth reflects on the consequences of her actions and the impact of Lydia's elopement on her relationship with Mr. Darcy. She regrets her past decisions and contemplates the lost opportunities.
text_phrases: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry
been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted
her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination

1630-1655.scene_title: Mr. Gardiner's Letter to Mr. Bennet
1630-1655.description: Mr. Gardiner writes to Mr. Bennet about Wickham's decision to quit the militia and the arrangements made for his debts. He expresses his wishes for the welfare of the family and requests that the subject of Wickham's debts not be mentioned again.
1630-1655.dialog_summary: Mr. Gardiner informs Mr. Bennet of Wickham's plans to leave the militia and join the regulars, and discusses the arrangements made for his debts.
text_phrases: Mr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother
Mr. Wickham had resolved on quitting the Militia
It is Mr. Wickham's intention to go into the regulars
satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham

1630-1655.scene_title: Lydia and Wickham's Arrival at the Bennet Home
1630-1655.description: Lydia and Wickham arrive at the Bennet family home after their marriage. The family's reactions are mixed, with Mrs. Bennet showing delight and Mr. Bennet displaying disapproval. Lydia is exuberant and unabashed, while Elizabeth and Jane are discomforted by the situation.
1630-1655.dialog_summary: Lydia and Wickham are received with mixed emotions by the Bennet family. Lydia is lively and unreserved, while the family reacts variously with joy, disapproval, and embarrassment.
text_phrases: Lydia's voice was heard in the vestibule

1656-1685.description: Lydia Bennet excitedly recounts the details of her wedding day to her sister Elizabeth, despite Elizabeth's reluctance to discuss the topic.
1656-1685.dialog_summary: Lydia eagerly describes her wedding and the events leading up to it, including the last-minute return of her uncle who was to give her away. Elizabeth expresses disinterest and amazement, particularly when Lydia accidentally mentions Mr. Darcy's unexpected involvement.
text_phrases: sitting with her two elder sisters
my uncle and aunt and I were to go together
my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away
we breakfasted at ten as usual

1656-1685.description: After hearing an unexpected revelation from Lydia about Mr. Darcy's presence at her wedding, Elizabeth is consumed with curiosity and writes a letter to her aunt seeking explanations.
1656-1685.dialog_summary: Elizabeth debates internally about the implications of Mr. Darcy's involvement in Lydia's wedding and decides to write to her aunt for more information, expressing her intense curiosity and determination to uncover the truth.
text_phrases: hastily seizing a sheet of paper
wrote a short letter to her aunt
request an explanation of what Lydia had dropt

1686-1720.description: Mr. Darcy and Mr. Gardiner engage in discussions to settle matters concerning Wickham and Lydia. Mr. Darcy attempts to meet with Mr. Gardiner but only manages to do so after several attempts.
1686-1720.dialog_summary: Mr. Darcy and Mr. Gardiner discuss the financial and social arrangements needed to resolve the situation with Wickham and Lydia. Mr. Darcy is persistent and takes on the responsibility to settle things.
text_phrases: Mr. Darcy's next step was to make your uncle acquainted with it
Every thing being settled between them

1686-1720.description: Elizabeth reflects on the contents of a letter from her aunt, which discusses Mr. Darcy's efforts and intentions. She is then interrupted by Wickham during her walk.
1686-1720.dialog_summary: Wickham interrupts Elizabeth's solitary walk, and they discuss his past and his views on Darcy's activities in town. Elizabeth tries to silence Wickham's inquiries about Darcy.
text_phrases: Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits
I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?
Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him

1721-1765.description: Elizabeth and Mr. Wickham reconcile before entering the house, where Elizabeth extends a hand in friendship and Mr. Wickham responds with affectionate gallantry.
1721-1765.location: Front door of the Bennet's house
1721-1765.dialog_summary: Elizabeth tells Mr. Wickham they should not quarrel about the past and should be of one mind in the future. Mr. Wickham agrees and shows affection.
text_phrases: at the door of the house

1721-1765.scene_title: Departure of Lydia and Mr. Wickham
1721-1765.description: Lydia and Mr. Wickham prepare to leave, amidst emotional farewells and Mrs. Bennet's distress over the separation.
1721-1765.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet and Lydia exchange emotional farewells, discussing when they will meet again and the frequency of writing letters.
text_phrases: day of his and Lydia's departure
Mrs. Bennet was forced to submit to a separation

1721-1765.description: Mrs. Bennet reacts with mixed emotions to the news of Mr. Bingley's impending visit, brought by Mrs. Philips.
1721-1765.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips discuss Mr. Bingley's return, with Mrs. Bennet showing a pretense of indifference but secretly hopeful.
text_phrases: Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets
looked at Jane, and smiled, and shook her head by turns

1721-1765.scene_title: Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy's Arrival
1721-1765.description: Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy arrive at the Bennet's house, causing a stir among the family members, especially Elizabeth and Jane.
1721-1765.dialog_summary: The Bennet sisters and Mrs. Bennet discuss the arrival of Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy, with mixed reactions of welcome and discomfort.
text_phrases: saw him from her dressing-room window

1766-1810.description: Elizabeth feels distressed by Darcy's silence and lack of communication, reflecting on his behavior and her own expectations. Mrs. Bennet converses with Mr. Bingley about local news and her daughter's marriage.
1766-1810.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is upset by Darcy's silence and lack of engagement in conversation, feeling disappointed and confused. Mrs. Bennet talks to Mr. Bingley about the neighborhood changes and her daughter's marriage, expressing both pride and sadness.

1766-1810.description: Elizabeth reflects on Darcy's behavior and her own feelings, while Mrs. Bennet extends a dinner invitation to Mr. Bingley and discusses past engagements.
1766-1810.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is internally conflicted about Darcy's distant behavior, while Mrs. Bennet invites Bingley to dinner, reminiscing about his past promise to visit.
text_phrases: Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked

1766-1810.description: During a dinner party at Longbourn, Elizabeth observes the interactions between Darcy, Bingley, and Jane, noting the tension and unspoken feelings among them.
1766-1810.dialog_summary: Elizabeth watches the seating arrangements and interactions at dinner, feeling anxious about Darcy's behavior and her mother's lack of tact.
text_phrases: When they repaired to the dining-room
Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked

1811-1858.description: During an evening gathering, the tea-things are cleared, card tables are set up, and Elizabeth hopes to interact with a certain gentleman, but is disappointed as he is occupied with playing whist. Mrs. Bennet expresses her satisfaction with the day's events and praises the dinner and guests.
1811-1858.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet praises the day's events and the quality of dinner, expressing satisfaction and mentioning the beauty of Jane and the good behavior of other guests. She is optimistic about Jane's prospects with Mr. Bingley.
text_phrases: seated with the rest of the party
his eyes were so often turned

1811-1858.description: Mrs. Bennet attempts to manage the social interactions of her daughters and Mr. Bingley during an evening at home, aiming to create opportunities for Jane and Mr. Bingley to be alone.
1811-1858.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet tries to orchestrate situations where Jane and Mr. Bingley can be alone, but her plans are not very effective. She communicates through hints and winks, which are mostly ignored by Elizabeth and Catherine.
text_phrases: Mr. Bennet retired to the library
Mary went up stairs to her instrument
Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking
took her out of the room

1859-1917.description: Mr. Bennet speaks to Jane about her future happiness after their visitor leaves, expressing his pleasure and concerns about her disposition and future challenges.
1859-1917.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet congratulates Jane on her future prospects, expressing both joy and concern about her and her future husband's temperaments and their potential financial imprudence.

1859-1917.description: Lady Catherine de Bourgh makes an unexpected visit to the Bennet family early in the morning, leading to a walk with Elizabeth where she confronts her about the rumors of an engagement with Mr. Darcy.
1859-1917.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine arrives unexpectedly, refuses refreshments, and demands Elizabeth to walk with her. She confronts Elizabeth about the rumors of her engagement to Mr. Darcy, insisting on a denial.
text_phrases: Lady Catherine de Bourgh makes an unexpected visit

1918-1962.description: Elizabeth Bennet and Lady Catherine de Bourgh have a heated exchange regarding Elizabeth's potential engagement to Mr. Darcy. Lady Catherine attempts to assert her wishes while Elizabeth stands her ground.
1918-1962.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine confronts Elizabeth about her rumored engagement to Mr. Darcy, asserting claims based on family connections and societal expectations. Elizabeth refutes her claims, emphasizing her own views on happiness and independence.
text_phrases: at the door of the carriage
at the door of the dressing-room

1963-1995.scene_title: Elizabeth and Mr. Bennet Discuss a Letter
1963-1995.description: Elizabeth follows her father, Mr. Bennet, into his room where he shares the contents of a surprising letter concerning Elizabeth's impending matrimony, which he humorously attributes to Mr. Collins.
1963-1995.location: Mr. Bennet's room in the Bennet family home
1963-1995.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet reveals the contents of a letter from Mr. Collins, which includes congratulations on supposed upcoming nuptials involving Elizabeth, much to her surprise and confusion.
text_phrases: colour now rushed into Elizabeth's cheeks

1963-1995.description: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy walk together, during which Elizabeth thanks him for his kindness towards her sister Lydia, leading to a heartfelt conversation about their feelings.
1963-1995.dialog_summary: Elizabeth expresses gratitude to Mr. Darcy for his help with Lydia, which leads to a deeper conversation about their personal feelings and a mutual understanding of their affection for each other.
text_phrases: moment for her resolution to be executed
thanking you for your unexampled kindness

1996-2042.description: Darcy and Elizabeth engage in a deep and reflective conversation, discussing past actions, misunderstandings, and the evolution of their feelings towards each other.
1996-2042.dialog_summary: Darcy and Elizabeth discuss their past misunderstandings and misjudgments, expressing regret and acknowledging each other's changes and growth. Darcy reflects on his previous arrogance and credits Elizabeth for his transformation.
text_phrases: She explained what its effect on her had been

1996-2042.description: Elizabeth and Darcy continue their walk, discussing their personal growth and the events that led to their current understanding and feelings.
1996-2042.dialog_summary: Darcy explains his actions and intentions behind his letter to Elizabeth, expressing his initial bitterness and subsequent regret. Elizabeth reflects on her changed perceptions and acknowledges her happiness.
text_phrases: He then told her of Georgiana's delight
they found at last, on examining their watches

1996-2042.description: Elizabeth returns home after her walk with Darcy, facing her family's inquiries about her whereabouts. The evening passes with mixed emotions among the family members.
1996-2042.dialog_summary: Elizabeth is questioned by Jane and the rest of the family about her long walk. The evening is marked by a mix of emotions, with acknowledged and unacknowledged lovers displaying different behaviors.
text_phrases: At night she opened her heart to Jane

2043-2081.description: Elizabeth and Jane discuss Elizabeth's feelings for Mr. Darcy and her previous secrecy about the relationship.
2043-2081.dialog_summary: Elizabeth and Jane discuss Elizabeth's affection for Mr. Darcy, her previous reluctance to discuss her feelings, and the gradual realization of her love starting from her first visit to Pemberley.
text_phrases: first seeing his beautiful grounds at Pemberley

2043-2081.description: Elizabeth and Mrs. Bennet discuss Mr. Darcy's frequent visits and Mrs. Bennet's plan for Elizabeth to spend time with him.
2043-2081.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet expresses her annoyance at Mr. Darcy's visits and suggests Elizabeth walk with him. Elizabeth finds the situation amusing but vexing.

2043-2081.description: Elizabeth and Mr. Bennet discuss her impending engagement to Mr. Darcy, addressing her father's concerns and her affirmations of love.
2043-2081.dialog_summary: Mr. Bennet questions Elizabeth's decision to marry Mr. Darcy, expressing concerns about happiness and respect in their marriage. Elizabeth reassures him of her genuine affection and respect for Mr. Darcy.

2043-2081.description: Elizabeth informs Mrs. Bennet of her engagement to Mr. Darcy, leading to an overwhelmed and ecstatic reaction from Mrs. Bennet.
2043-2081.dialog_summary: Mrs. Bennet is initially speechless upon hearing of Elizabeth's engagement to Mr. Darcy, then becomes overly excited about the prospects of wealth and status the marriage will bring.

2082-2120.scene_title: Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy's Playful Banter
2082-2120.description: Elizabeth playfully questions Mr. Darcy about the origins of his feelings for her, leading to a deep and reflective conversation about their past interactions and feelings.
2082-2120.dialog_summary: Elizabeth teases Mr. Darcy about how he started loving her despite her impertinence. Mr. Darcy admits he was drawn to her lively mind. They discuss their initial misunderstandings and Mr. Darcy's intentions when visiting Netherfield.
text_phrases: Elizabeth's spirits soon rising to playfulness
Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her
Mr. Darcy admits he was drawn to her lively mind

2082-2120.description: Elizabeth responds to Mrs. Gardiner's letter with news of her engagement to Mr. Darcy, expressing her happiness and plans for the future. Meanwhile, Mr. Bennet and Miss Bingley send their own letters regarding the engagement.
2082-2120.dialog_summary: Elizabeth writes to Mrs. Gardiner about her happiness and future plans. Mr. Bennet and Miss Bingley also send letters expressing their views on Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy's engagement.
text_phrases: Elizabeth responds to Mrs. Gardiner's letter
news of her engagement to Mr. Darcy
expressing her happiness and plans for the future
Mr. Bennet and Miss Bingley send their own letters

2082-2120.scene_title: The Collinses' Arrival at Lucas Lodge
2082-2120.description: The Collinses arrive at Lucas Lodge to escape Lady Catherine's anger over Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy's engagement. Elizabeth finds pleasure in their company despite the awkwardness caused by Mr. Darcy's presence.
2082-2120.dialog_summary: The Collinses discuss their sudden move to Lucas Lodge due to Lady Catherine's displeasure. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy navigate the social dynamics with the Lucas family and Mrs. Philips.
text_phrases: The Collinses arrive at Lucas Lodge
Elizabeth finds pleasure in their company
awkwardness caused by Mr. Darcy's presence

2121-2131.description: Lydia writes a congratulatory letter to Elizabeth on her marriage to Mr. Darcy, expressing hopes for financial assistance and a position for Wickham.
2121-2131.dialog_summary: Lydia congratulates Elizabeth and subtly hints at financial needs and desires for Wickham to secure a position.
text_phrases: The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia
If you love Mr. Darcy half as well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy

2121-2131.scene_title: Financial Struggles and Movements of Lydia and Wickham
2121-2131.description: Lydia and Wickham, despite their constant moving and financial imprudence, occasionally visit Pemberley, where their presence sometimes overstays its welcome.
2121-2131.dialog_summary: Lydia and Wickham's financial struggles and movements are discussed, along with their visits to Pemberley and the strain it sometimes causes.
text_phrases: always moving from place to place
always spending more than they ought

2121-2131.description: Lady Catherine initially reacts with extreme indignation to the news of Darcy's marriage to Elizabeth, but eventually seeks reconciliation influenced by Elizabeth.
2121-2131.dialog_summary: Lady Catherine is initially furious about Darcy's marriage but is persuaded by Elizabeth to reconcile.
